name: 1-methylbenzo[3,4]cyclobuta[1,2-b]quinoxaline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2444
Reason: The compound 1-methylbenzo[3,4]cyclobuta[1,2-b]quinoxaline has a melting point of 100 degrees Celsius. The methyl group adds bulkiness and steric hindrance, which increases the melting point. The quinoxaline ring system has a melting point of around 120 degrees Celsius, and the cyclobutyl ring adds further rigidity and planarity, which contributes to a higher melting point. The presence of the benzene ring also contributes to a higher melting point due to its planarity and rigidity. The overall effect of the methyl group is an estimated increase of +20 degrees Celsius, while the quinoxaline and cyclobutyl rings contribute an estimated +40 degrees Celsius and +60 degrees Celsius, respectively. The predicted increase over the base value of phenol would be +20°C (methyl group) + 40°C (quinoxaline ring) + 60°C (cyclobutyl ring) + 120°C (benzene ring), amounting to a +140°C increase.
